conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (emf) in the coil, we need to use Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.

The emf induced in a coil rotating in a uniform magnetic field can be described by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \) where: - \( n \) is the number of turns of the coil, - \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, - \( A \) is the area of the coil, - \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, - \( t \) is the time.
Since we start timing when the coil plane passes through the neutral plane, \( t = 0 \), and thus \( \sin(\omega t) = \sin(0) = 0 \).
The maximum emf occurs when \( \sin(\omega t) = 1 \), so we can find the peak emf.

premise: The area \( A \) of the coil is calculated as \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2 \, \text{m} \times 0.5 \, \text{m} = 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \).
conclusion: The area of the coil is \( 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \).

premise: Substitute the given values into the formula for the peak emf: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{peak}} = n B A \omega \).
